review.title: Synthesis of supervised classification algorithm using intelligent and statistical tools
review.abstract: A fundamental task in detecting foreground objects in both static and dynamic scenes is to take the best choice of color system representation and the efficient technique for background modeling. We propose in this paper a non-parametric algorithm dedicated to segment and to detect objects in color images issued from a football sports meeting. Indeed segmentation by pixel concern many applications and revealed how the method is robust to detect objects, even in presence of strong shadows and highlights. In the other hand to refine their playing strategy such as in football, handball, volley ball, Rugby..., the coach need to have a maximum of technical-tactics information about the on-going of the game and the players. We propose in this paper a range of algorithms allowing the resolution of many problems appearing in the automated process of team identification, where each player is affected to his corresponding team relying on visual data. The developed system was tested on a match of the Tunisian national competition. This work is prominent for many next computer vision studies as it's detailed in this study.

sections.heading: A. Detection by histogram analysis
sections.text: In the artificial visual field, color images are captured by a video camera and then digitized by a computer. As the football video is captured by a static camera, the trailer and useless information can be removed by delimiting the play zone with an affinity function. Object recognition in color images is a relevant step in the classification study; therefore, we start by subtracting the background to recognize the players and then classify each of them into their appropriate class. The algorithm is based on the following steps: Convert the original image to default values rgb values and remove the light reflections. Recognize the high and low thresholds of each histogram and then perform the threshold on the three chromatic levels. Apply a logical "AND" on the three levels and the original images.

sections.heading: B. Detection by statistical learning
sections.text: Recognition by histogram analysis consists in segmenting color images and removing useless information that does not contribute to the classification phase. This method is not a good choice of segmentation for many applications, as shown in Figure 2. The main problem of this technique corresponds to the time when background and foreground have the same characteristics, so many false detections may occur after the histogram threshold: for example, it can remove a large amount of useful information, so we should develop an appropriate technique. As the parametric background model still lacks flexibility in dealing with nonstatic backgrounds, a highly flexible nonparametric technique is proposed for estimating background probabilities from many newer samples using the nuclear density estimation. In the nonparametric model, all recently observed pixel values x1, x2... xN are flexible in dealing with nonstatic backgrounds, a high-grade nonparametric technique for determining nuclear density, with the band density function being chosen as the final gauge function, often being the gauge density function.

In fact, other color systems derived from the RGB components may be more appropriate depending on the case under consideration. metadata.abstractText: A fundamental task in detecting foreground objects in both static and dynamic scenes is to take the best choice of color system representation and the efficient technique for background modeling. We propose in this paper a non-parametric algorithm dedicated to segment and to detect objects in color images issued from a football sports meeting. Indeed segmentation by pixel concern many applications and revealed how the method is robust to detect objects, even in presence of strong shadows and highlights. In the other hand to refine their playing strategy such as in football, handball, volley ball, Rugby..., the coach need to have a maximum of technical-tactics information about the on-going of the game and the players. We propose in this paper a range of algorithms allowing the resolution of many problems appearing in the automated process of team identification, where each player is affected to his corresponding team relying on visual data. The developed system was tested on a match of the Tunisian national competition. This work is prominent for many next computer vision studies as it’s detailed in this study.
